[patient] yes . yes . all my kids-
[doctor] okay .

[doctor] okay . great . i'm glad to hear that . now , i know you did a review of systems sheet when you checked in .
[patient] yes .
[doctor] i , are you having any symptoms ? any chest pain , shortness of breath , belly pain , of , nausea or vomiting ? anything like that ?
[patient] no . no symptoms at all .
[doctor] okay , great . um , well , let me go ahead . i wan na do a quick physical exam .
[doctor] hey , dragon . show me the vital signs .
[doctor] so , your vital signs here in the office look really good . so , you're doing a great job managing your , your blood pressure . your heart rate's nice and low . i'm gon na go ahead and take a listen to your heart and lungs .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] and i'll let you know what i find . okay ?
[patient] okay .
[doctor] okay . good . all right . so , on physical examination , i , i do n't hear any carotid bruits in your neck , which is really good . you know , your heart exam , i do hear a slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur , which i've heard in the past , so that's stable . uh , your lungs are nice and clear , and you do have , you know , 1+ pitting edema bilaterally in your lower extremities .

[doctor] so , what does that mean ? you know , i , i think , you know , you're doing a ... it sounds like a doing a good job watching your diet . you could ... you just are retaining a little bit of fluid , maybe just from standing all day .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] okay ? let's take a look at some of your results . okay ?
[patient] okay .
[doctor] hey , dragon . show me the endoscope results .

[patient] okay .
[patient] i'll do a little more exercise too .
[doctor] that sounds great . all right . so , let's talk just a little bit about , you know , my assessment and my plan for you .
[doctor] for your reflux , i want you to continue on the protonix 40 mg a day , and continue with those lifestyle modifications with the dietary stuff-
[patient] okay .
[doctor] . okay ? do you have any questions ?

[patient] okay . thank you .

output.text:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Alexander Myers is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for reflux who presents for follow-up of his chronic problems.

In regards to his reflux, he reports that he has continued to utilize Protonix 40 mg daily. He states this has helped a lot and he is really comfortable. The patient is doing really well with his diet. He reports that he has discontinued drinking energy drinks and is now drinking green tea. The patient states this change has also helped reduce his side effects.

He notes that his reflux being improved has helped his mood. The patient has a good support system at home and all of his children call to check on him daily. He also notes his job is going well.

The patient denies chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neurological/Psychological: Appropriate mood and affect.
• Neck: No carotid bruits appreciable.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate. Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: 1+ pitting edema bilaterally in the lower extremities.

RESULTS

Endoscopy from last year revealed mild gastritis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Alexander Myers is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for acid reflux. He presents today for follow up of his chronic problems.

Acid reflux.
• Medical Reasoning: This is well controlled on Protonix and dietary modifications.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Protonix 40 mg daily.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I advised the patient to continue with lifestyle and dietary modifications.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

completions.text:
# Clinical Note

## HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Alexander is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for reflux who presents for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports significant improvement in his reflux symptoms since starting Protonix. He states he can now eat whatever he wants without discomfort. He has made lifestyle modifications including switching from energy drinks to green tea. The patient denies any current symptoms including chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting. He reports improved mood since his reflux has been better controlled. The patient has good social support with his children checking on him daily.

## PHYSICAL EXAM
Vital signs: Within normal limits with well-controlled blood pressure and low heart rate.
Cardiovascular: No carotid bruits. 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable from previous exams.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation.
Extremities: 1+ bilateral pitting edema in lower extremities.

## RESULTS
Endoscopy from last year showed mild gastritis.

## ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
1. Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
   - Continue Protonix 40 mg daily
   - Continue lifestyle modifications including dietary changes
   - Patient encouraged to increase exercise to help with lower extremity edema

Patient has no questions and will follow up as scheduled.

For each of the following criteria, rate the response on a scale of 1 to 5 (1 = very poor, 5 = excellent),
and provide a short justification for your score.

Evaluation Criteria:
Accuracy (1-5)
- Does the note provide correct clinical information based on the conversation?

Completeness (1-5)
- Does the note include all important medical details from the conversation?

Clarity (1-5)
- Is the note written clearly and organized in a standard clinical format for clinicians

Output Format:
Output the evaluation as a single valid JSON object matching the following structure:
{
    "accuracy": {
        "score": 0,
        "explanation": "Explain why this score was given."
    },
    "completeness": {

Ensure the output is valid JSON:

- When quoting text or sections inside the explanations, use escaped double quotes (") to
  maintain valid JSON formatting.
- Do not include any additional information in the output.

accuracy.explanation: Most details match the conversation: well-controlled reflux on Protonix 40 mg, lifestyle change from energy drinks to green tea, denial of chest pain/SOB/abdominal pain/nausea/vomiting, clear lungs, stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, no carotid bruits, 1+ bilateral LE edema, and prior endoscopy showing mild gastritis. One inaccuracy: the note states the patient was "encouraged to increase exercise to help with lower extremity edema," which was not advised by the clinician; the patient volunteered "I'll do a little more exercise" and the clinician attributed edema possibly to standing all day.

completeness.explanation: Covers core elements from the visit (HPI, PE findings including edema and murmur, results, plan for GERD, social support, mood improvement). Minor omissions: lacks an explicit chief complaint section, a distinct ROS section, and does not document the clinician’s comment that edema may be from standing all day. These do not materially affect understanding of the visit.

clarity.explanation: Well organized with standard sections (HPI, Physical Exam, Results, Assessment and Plan). Language is concise and clinically readable. The structure aligns with typical clinical documentation and is easy to follow.

input.text:
Doctor-patient dialogue:

[doctor] amanda taylor , birth date october 31st 1949 . patient is a 72 year old woman who comes for followup for hypertension . her history includes significant alcohol use disorder and mi- mild hypercholesterolemia . at last visit on april 16th her blood pressure was 130 over 90 . after presenting at 150 over 100 she was prescribed hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 milligrams by mouth once daily , and lisinopril 20 milligrams by mouth once daily . cmp and cbc were essentially unremarkable .
[doctor] hi miss taylor , how are you today ?
[patient] hi , i'm- i'm good , thank you .
[doctor] thanks for coming in today .
[patient] yeah , no problem .
[doctor] so how have things been going for you ?
[patient] uh , they've been all right . i'm struggling with not drinking . i wanted to discuss that , uh , shot that you had mentioned last time , but we did n't get to discuss it too much .
[doctor] okay , well i'll be happy to provide you with more information . so tell me when did you last have a drink ?
[patient] on monday .
[doctor] okay , so you've gone a couple days without it ?
[patient] yeah , yeah i have .
[doctor] yeah , and had you been drinking for a while ?
[patient] yep .
[doctor] how much had- how much had you been drinking ?
[patient] um , four or five times a week hard alcohol , so , you know .
[doctor] okay . well it will certainly help your blood pressure if you're able to stop drinking .
[patient] yeah , yeah i- i- i agree with you .
[doctor] okay . are you taking your blood pressure medications ?
[patient] yeah , but i'm only taking half of the lisinopril .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] i- b- well , the first time i took it i felt lethargic and tired , so i only took a half dose the next time . i felt much better and i did n't have the headaches or the swooshing that started in my left ear . so i feel like it's definitely helping but i do n't know ... i know it's not gon na be okay until i stop drinking .
[doctor] and are you also taking the full dose of the hydrochlorothiazide ? do you have any , um , chest tightness or pressure or any shortness of breath ?
[patient] yeah i'm taking the full dose of that medicine too , and no none of those symptoms .
[doctor] okay . anything else i should be aware of or that we should be checking ?
[patient] mm , no .
[doctor] okay , good . are you doing the blood pressure checks at home ?
[patient] yes . yes i am .
[doctor] okay good . what kind of numbers are you seeing ?
[patient] well , in the morning i'm seeing lower numbers than in the evening , um , where i run anywhere from like 130 to 145 or 150 over 95 to 100 on the bottom .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] but in the evenings if i sit there for a while and then take it , it goes down . kind of like when i come here it's always high but then it goes down . in the mornings it's generally more normal where it's supposed to be .
[doctor] uh- .
[patient] mm , also i'm taking my medicine in the morning when i get up instead of in the evening .
[doctor] yeah , so it sounds like we are not too far out of where we wan na be .
[patient] right , mm-hmm .
[doctor] okay . well let me get a listen to your heart , go ahead and hop up here .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] use my general exam template . all right , go ahead and take some deep breaths . okay , good . any fever , cough , shortness of breath or sore throat ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] any recent travel or contact or exposure to the coronavirus ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] have you received your coronavirus vaccine ?
[patient] yes , on february 9th .
[doctor] okay , great . all right well i'm just going to look at your ankles and feet , i'm looking for any signs of swelling .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] all right , well everything looks good . you can go ahead and sit up miss taylor . all right , so the good news is everything is looking okay . i think we both agree if you were able to stop drinking your blood pressure would cease to be an issue for you .
[patient] yeah i agree with that .
[doctor] so let us discuss the potential medicine to help you with that . what it does is it blocks some of the brain receptors that alcohol stimulates and it tricks the brain into thinking it does not need alcohol , thereby cutting down the urges .
[patient] the urge to drink or the constant thinking about it ?
[doctor] it actually will help with both .
[patient] okay . so is it like a one-time thing ?
[doctor] generally the shot is given about once a month , it can also be given as a daily pill , but the shot does tend to work a bit better .
[patient] yeah i've taken things like this in the past and if it is a pill , i know i wo n't take it . with a shot , it's not like you can un-take it .
[doctor] yeah that's true . and the shot has been shown to work , it is more just a matter of getting you in to get your shot a month later with the nurse .
[patient] yeah , sure , sure .
[doctor] okay , so it's called naltrexone . i think the other name might be vivitrol . like i've said , the research on it is pretty good .
[patient] i think i may have taken the naltrexone before .
[doctor] okay , yeah , maybe you have .
[patient] yeah , if it was available in a pill form then i'm almost certain i've tried it b- before .
[doctor] okay . if this sounds good though , we can go ahead get you started with the shot . i am looking and it looks like we have you coming back in on may 17th for your first shot , does that sound good ?
[patient] yeah , yeah , that sounds great . are there any possible side effects ?
[doctor] yeah , some people will experience some nausea , headache , dizziness , anxi- anxiety , tiredness and trouble sleeping , but generally the side effects are mild and should go away within a few days .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] then we can schedule you for a follow-up in june to see how you are doing .
[patient] all right that sounds good .
[doctor] all right great . well otherwise stay with your current medicines , keep checking your blood pressure , and let's see if we can stop the alcohol for good . let us know if you have any questions or any issues come up after you receive the first dose .
[patient] all right , sounds good , thank you .
[doctor] you are welcome , have a good rest of your day .
[patient] you too .
[doctor] miss taylor is drinking alcohol four to five days per week to excess . no tobacco , no substance abuse , skin is moist , good trigger . on exam she is alert , pleasant , in no acute distress . she is not diabetic , there is no tremor , no cva tenderness , chest clear to percussion and auscultation , unlabored breathing , cardiac rhythm regular , no murmur , no gallop , jvp flat , with a head at 90 degrees . she does not appear anxious , agitated or depressed . my impression , alcohol use disorder . she would like to start naltrexone which we have previously discussed . she will take the injectable form and start on may 17th . we reviewed side effects and risks . the potential benefit of alcohol cessation would be highly beneficial to her for many reasons . hypertension , she is taking lisinopril 10 milligrams daily and hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 milligrams daily . quite possibly her blood pressure will improve completely with cessation of alcohol . her target bp is 130 to 140 over 70 to 80 . i will see her back week of june 14th , which is likely around the time of her second naltrexone injection . i recommend upgrading influenza vaccination and shingrix . number two , she did defer this .

output.text:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Hypertension.
Alcohol use disorder.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Amanda Taylor is an 72-year-old woman who presents for a follow-up for hypertension. History includes significant alcohol use disorder and mild hypercholesterolemia. # Clinical Note

## HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Amanda Taylor is a 72-year-old female who presents for follow-up of hypertension. Her medical history includes significant alcohol use disorder and mild hypercholesterolemia. At her last visit on April 16, her blood pressure was 130/90, improved from 150/100 after starting hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg daily and lisinopril 20 mg daily. The patient reports taking the full dose of hydrochlorothiazide but only half the dose of lisinopril (10 mg) due to experiencing lethargy, tiredness, headaches, and "swooshing" in her left ear with the full dose. She is performing home blood pressure monitoring with morning readings in the normal range and evening readings ranging from 130-150/95-100. The patient admits to ongoing alcohol consumption, drinking hard alcohol 4-5 times per week, with her last drink on Monday (2 days prior to this visit). She expresses interest in naltrexone injection therapy to help with alcohol cessation, which was previously discussed. She reports no chest tightness, pressure, shortness of breath, fever, cough, or sore throat.

## PHYSICAL EXAM
- General: Alert, pleasant, in no acute distress
- Skin: Moist, good turgor
- Neurological: No tremor
- Respiratory: Chest clear to percussion and auscultation, unlabored breathing
- Cardiovascular: Regular cardiac rhythm, no murmur, no gallop, JVP flat with head at 90 degrees
- Renal: No CVA tenderness
- Extremities: No ankle or foot swelling
- Psychiatric: Does not appear anxious, agitated, or depressed

## RESULTS
Previous CMP and CBC were essentially unremarkable. Home blood pressure readings show morning values within normal range and evening values ranging from 130-150/95-100.

## ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
1. Alcohol Use Disorder
   - Patient to start injectable naltrexone (Vivitrol) on May 17
   - Reviewed side effects including possible nausea, headache, dizziness, anxiety, tiredness, and trouble sleeping
   - Discussed benefits of alcohol cessation, particularly for blood pressure control

2. Hypertension
   - Currently on hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg daily and lisinopril 10 mg daily (self-reduced from 20 mg)
   - Target BP: 130-140/70-80
   - Continue current regimen with home monitoring
   - Blood pressure likely to improve with alcohol cessation

3. Follow-up
   - Return visit scheduled for week of June 14, coinciding with second naltrexone injection
   - Recommended influenza vaccination and Shingrix, which patient deferred

CC:

Left shoulder pain.

HPI:

Ms. Anderson is a 44-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of the left shoulder. She states that she was in gymnastics 1 week ago. The pain has been present since that time. She has pain with any type of movement of her left shoulder. She had taken Tylenol for 2 to 3 days with no improvement in her symptoms.

She has a surgical history significant for prior left upper extremity surgery.

EXAM

Examination of the left shoulder shows pain with range of motion.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder, 3 views obtained on today's visit show no obvious signs of fracture.

PLAN

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended taking ibuprofen 600 mg three times per day for one week. If the patient does not have relief from the ibuprofen she will take Aleve. The patient may also utilize ice or heat packs. She should rest her left arm and may not lift or carry heavy objects with her left arm. The patient should follow up in three to four weeks if the pain persists. We may repeat the left shoulder x-ray at that time.

# Clinical Note

## HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Mrs. Anderson is a 44-year-old female presenting with left shoulder pain that has persisted for one week. The pain began during a gymnastics class when she believes she "toppled over into some weird position" while performing a certain move. She reports pain with any movement of the left shoulder. The patient initially self-treated with Tylenol for 2-3 days without relief. She mentions a past surgery on her left arm but does not believe it is related to her current pain. She has not taken any other pain medications.

## PHYSICAL EXAM
Physical examination reveals pain with movement of the left shoulder in all directions. Patient experiences discomfort with both forward and backward shoulder movement.

## RESULTS
X-ray of the left shoulder shows no evidence of fracture or broken bone.

## ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
1. Left shoulder pain, likely joint strain/sprain from gymnastics activity
2. Plan:
   - Ibuprofen 600mg three times daily for one week
   - Apply ice or heat pad for pain relief
   - Rest left arm for 3-4 weeks
   - Avoid lifting heavy weights
   - Use right arm instead of left for daily activities
   - Follow-up in 3 weeks if pain persists
   - Alternative OTC pain relievers suggested: Advil or Aleve
   - Patient instructed to call for earlier appointment if pain worsens

<response>
# Clinical Note

## HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Mrs. Anderson is a 44-year-old female presenting with left shoulder pain that has persisted for one week. The pain began during a gymnastics class when she believes she "toppled over into some weird position" while performing a certain move. She reports pain with any movement of the left shoulder. The patient initially self-treated with Tylenol for 2-3 days without relief. She mentions a past surgery on her left arm but does not believe it is related to her current pain. She has not taken any other pain medications.

## PHYSICAL EXAM
Physical examination reveals pain with movement of the left shoulder in all directions. Patient experiences discomfort with both forward and backward shoulder movement.

## RESULTS
X-ray of the left shoulder shows no evidence of fracture or broken bone.

## ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
1. Left shoulder pain, likely joint strain/sprain from gymnastics activity
2. Plan:
   - Ibuprofen 600mg three times daily for one week
   - Apply ice or heat pad for pain relief
   - Rest left arm for 3-4 weeks
   - Avoid lifting heavy weights
   - Use right arm instead of left for daily activities
   - Follow-up in 3 weeks if pain persists
   - Alternative OTC pain relievers suggested: Advil or Aleve
   - Patient instructed to call for earlier appointment if pain worsens
</response>

output.text:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up for perioral dermatitis.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Jacqueline Miller is a 40-year-old female who is being seen today for a follow-up skin exam for perioral dermatitis. She also has a history of rosacea, including ocular rosacea. Today, she states that her perioral dermatitis is well-controlled, although it has not fully resolved. The patient was applying doxycycline twice a day with improvement, but her pharmacist advised her to reduce to once daily since it had started to improve; therefore, for approximately the past week, she has been using the doxycycline only once per day. She has not seen continued improvement but it has not worsened. She is using the sulfacetamide wash twice daily, denies drying of the skin, and reports that her skin is much improved moisturization. She also applies MetroCream immediately after using the sulfacetamide wash. She denies using other lotions and products, Cetaphil lotion or soap, or Neutrogena wipes. The patient did not begin Elidel because it is not covered by her insurance, and she was concerned about possible side effects from the medication.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Perioral dermatitis.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Doxycycline cream. Apply twice daily.
MetroCream. 
Sulfacetamide wash. Apply topically twice daily.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Integumentary
Skin inspection of the face was performed today. On bilateral medial cheeks, there are a few, very faint, erythematous papules with mild redness around and underneath the nostrils. Fitzpatrick skin type is 4 to 5.

ASSESSMENT

• Perioral dermatitis
• Rosacea, including ocular rosacea

Jacqueline Miller is a 40-year-old female who presented today for follow-up for her perioral dermatitis, which has improved but not resolved. She decreased her doxycycline per her pharmacist’s recommendation, which possibly stagnated the resolution of symptoms.

PLAN

Perioral dermatitis.
I counseled the patient about the risks and benefits of doxycycline and recommended she resume twice daily application until she reaches full resolution, and at that point she should reduce application to once a day for an additional week. The patient will not be using Elidel as I reviewed the cost of the medication and without insurance, it was too expensive. I provided a prescription for Tacrolimus and counseled her on possible side effects of using the medication. She will continue with Sulfacetamide face wash once a day. Also, use Bruder mask as needed.

Rosacea, including ocular rosacea.
Continue using MetroCream twice daily. I recommended to gently wash her eyelids once daily with a gentle cleanser and try a gentle cream such as Vanicream.

INSTRUCTIONS

Call the clinic if symptoms worsen. The patient will have a follow-up appointment in 4 weeks.

completions.text:
# CLINICAL NOTE

## HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Jacqueline Miller presents for follow-up of facial rash. Patient reports improvement with previously prescribed doxycycline when taking it twice daily for the first two weeks. She then reduced to once daily last week per pharmacist suggestion, but notes the improvement has plateaued with some residual rash still present. Patient is no longer breastfeeding. She has been using sulfacetamide wash twice daily and metro cream after washing, but has not been using the prescribed Elidel due to concerns about side effects after reading about it. Patient denies using any other cleansers, wipes, or moisturizers currently. She reports sun sensitivity with doxycycline and has been taking precautions by wearing a hat when outdoors.

## PHYSICAL EXAM
Patient is Fitzpatrick skin type IV-V. Examination reveals a few faint erythematous papules on bilateral medial cheeks and mild erythema around and underneath the nostrils. Overall, the rash is improved but not completely resolved.

## RESULTS
No laboratory or diagnostic test results discussed during this visit.

## ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
1. Perioral dermatitis, rosacea, including ocular rosacea
   - Resume doxycycline twice daily until rash resolves, then once daily for one week before stopping
   - Continue sulfacetamide wash (once daily to avoid excessive drying)
   - Continue metro cream application after washing
   - Prescribed tacrolimus ointment (instead of Elidel due to cost concerns) to be applied to affected areas twice daily until resolved
   - Provided samples of basic moisturizer (Vanicream)
   - For ocular symptoms: gently wash eyelids once daily with gentle cleanser such as Vanicream; use Bruder mask as needed
   - Avoid steroids on face as they can worsen the condition and cause skin thinning
   - Avoid anti-aging products and plant-based products
   - Advised to consult before trying any new skin products
   - Continue sun protection measures while on doxycycline
   - Follow-up appointment scheduled in approximately 4 weeks
   - If rash worsens rather than improves, patient instructed to contact provider via MyChart or phone

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up for perioral dermatitis.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Jacqueline Miller is a 40-year-old female who is being seen today for a follow-up skin exam for perioral dermatitis. She also has a history of rosacea, including ocular rosacea. Today, she states that her perioral dermatitis is well-controlled, although it has not fully resolved. The patient was applying doxycycline twice a day with improvement, but her pharmacist advised her to reduce to once daily since it had started to improve; therefore, for approximately the past week, she has been using the doxycycline only once per day. She has not seen continued improvement but it has not worsened. She is using the sulfacetamide wash twice daily, denies drying of the skin, and reports that her skin is much improved moisturization. She also applies MetroCream immediately after using the sulfacetamide wash. She denies using other lotions and products, Cetaphil lotion or soap, or Neutrogena wipes. The patient did not begin Elidel because it is not covered by her insurance, and she was concerned about possible side effects from the medication.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Perioral dermatitis.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Doxycycline cream. Apply twice daily.
MetroCream. 
Sulfacetamide wash. Apply topically twice daily.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Integumentary
Skin inspection of the face was performed today. On bilateral medial cheeks, there are a few, very faint, erythematous papules with mild redness around and underneath the nostrils. Fitzpatrick skin type is 4 to 5.

ASSESSMENT

• Perioral dermatitis
• Rosacea, including ocular rosacea

Jacqueline Miller is a 40-year-old female who presented today for follow-up for her perioral dermatitis, which has improved but not resolved. She decreased her doxycycline per her pharmacist’s recommendation, which possibly stagnated the resolution of symptoms.

PLAN

Perioral dermatitis.
I counseled the patient about the risks and benefits of doxycycline and recommended she resume twice daily application until she reaches full resolution, and at that point she should reduce application to once a day for an additional week. The patient will not be using Elidel as I reviewed the cost of the medication and without insurance, it was too expensive. I provided a prescription for Tacrolimus and counseled her on possible side effects of using the medication. She will continue with Sulfacetamide face wash once a day. Also, use Bruder mask as needed.

Rosacea, including ocular rosacea.
Continue using MetroCream twice daily. I recommended to gently wash her eyelids once daily with a gentle cleanser and try a gentle cream such as Vanicream.

INSTRUCTIONS

Call the clinic if symptoms worsen. The patient will have a follow-up appointment in 4 weeks.

output.text:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne Jenkins is a pleasant 43-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of a right foot wound, onset 2 to 3 weeks ago. He was seen by his primary care physician who referred him to our office. His last visit with a podiatrist was 2 years ago, however they moved, and he has been unable to get another podiatrist. He denies any specific injury.

The patient purchased a new pair of shoes and was breaking them in prior to traveling. Initially, he did not feel that the shoes were too tight, however a blister formed on his right foot. The patient does have neuropathy and notes this might be why he did not notice the tightness. His blister soon became a wound and he was seen by his PCP. He was placed on a round of antibiotics, which he completed yesterday. He denies any changes to the appearance of the wound. The patient denies pain or drainage. His sock will occasionally stick to his wound, regardless of if he has a Band-Aid covering it. The patient has discontinued the use of these shoes. Occasionally, he has issues with stability, which was a primary purpose of purchasing these shoes. He denies any fever or chills.

Regarding his diabetes, his last hemoglobin A1C was 8.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever and chills.
Skin: Reports right foot wound.
Neurological: Reports neuropathy.

VITALS

Temperature: 98.1.
Heart rate: 72.
Respiration: 16.
Blood pressure: 110/65 mm Hg.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Palpable bilateral femoral and popliteal pulses. No palpable DP or PT pulses but Doppler signs are present. No evidence of fluid collection.
SKIN: On the right foot, there is a 1 x 2 inch circular wound on the dorsal aspect of the lateral right foot that is just proximal to the 5th MTP joint. There is some yellow slough present with minimal granulation tissue. No surrounding erythema or cellulitis. No necrosis. No odor.

RESULTS

3 views of the right foot were taken today. These reveal no evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT

1. Right foot diabetic ulcer.
2. Diabetes.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient regarding his current symptoms. I have explained to him that his x-rays did not reveal any evidence of osteomyelitis. At this time, I have recommended that we obtain an ankle brachial index ABI to determine the blood supply to his foot to see if he can heal this wound. I have also performed a debridement in the office to remove some of the dead tissue. I have prescribed a collagenase ointment to be applied to the wound 1 time daily and instructed him to cover with a dry sterile dressing. He will continue this until we see the wound shrinking and the nice pink tissue is present. I have also recommended that the patient be placed in a surgical shoe to take pressure off the area. I do not think that antibiotics are needed at this time. He may need to see a vascular specialist if the ABI indicates that his blood supply is not optimal for wound healing.

Regarding his diabetes, I explained the need for controlling his diabetes and the effects this will have on wound healing. I have recommended a diabetic consultation to discuss diet modifications to bring his hemoglobin A1c to a better level.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 2 weeks to check on his progress.

# CLINICAL NOTE

## HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Mr. Wayne presents with a non-healing wound on his right foot that has been present for 2-3 weeks. The wound initially started as a blister from new Hoka shoes he purchased for travel. Patient has peripheral neuropathy and cannot feel the wound. He reports no pain at the site. He completed a course of antibiotics prescribed by his PCP yesterday with no improvement in the wound. Patient notes that his sock sometimes sticks to the wound despite using band-aids. He denies fever, chills, or drainage. Patient has a history of diabetes with most recent HbA1c "a little over 8." He previously saw a podiatrist who has since relocated. Patient reports occasional issues with stability when walking.

## PHYSICAL EXAM
Vitals: Temperature 98.1°F, heart rate 72, respirations 16, blood pressure 110/65.

Foot exam: 1x2 inch circular wound on the dorsal aspect of the lateral right foot, just proximal to the right fifth MTP joint. Yellow slough present with minimal granulation tissue. No surrounding erythema, cellulitis, fluid collection, necrosis, odor, or bony exposure.

Vascular exam: Palpable bilateral femoral and popliteal pulses. No palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses, but Doppler signals are present.

## RESULTS
Right foot x-ray shows no evidence of osteomyelitis.

## ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
1. Diabetic foot ulcer:
   - Order ankle-brachial index (ABI) to assess blood supply to foot
   - Perform in-office debridement to remove dead tissue
   - Prescribe collagenase ointment to be applied once daily with dry sterile dressing
   - Patient to wear surgical shoe to offload pressure
   - No additional antibiotics needed at this time
   - Follow-up in 2 weeks
   - Possible vascular specialist referral if ABI indicates poor blood supply

2. Diabetes:
   - Emphasize importance of glycemic control for wound healing
   - Consider diabetic consultation for diet modification to improve HbA1c

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Ramirez is a 34-year-old female with a past medical history significant for hypertension, who presents today with back pain.

The patient reports she has been walking a lot lately, 30 minutes to an hour or so a day. While walking 6 days ago, she felt her back seize up on her. She is not sure what caused it but thinks she was walking a little faster than usual. She describes the sensation as a spasm. She has been taking ibuprofen and using heat on it but it is still pretty stiff. She denies any known trauma or injury to her back. She notes she has been weightlifting around 3 times a week. She did do deadlifts that day before her walk and thinks she may have been using her back more than her legs to lift. She locates the pain in her mid lower back. She denies any lower extremity numbness, tingling, and weakness.

Regarding her hypertension, she states she has been doing readings at home and that has been looking great. She has been watching her diet which has helped. She is taking lisinopril.

The patient endorses nasal congestion, which she attributes to her seasonal allergies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion from seasonal allergies.

# CLINICAL NOTE

## HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Cheryl is a 34-year-old female with a past medical history significant for hypertension who presents today with back pain. Patient reports that she has been walking 30-60 minutes daily and experienced sudden back "seizing up" about six days ago while walking. She describes it as a spasm-like sensation affecting her lower back bilaterally. She denies any specific trauma but mentions she has been lifting weights about three times weekly, including deadlifts on the day of the incident. She has been self-treating with ibuprofen and heat application, but reports continued stiffness. Patient denies numbness, tingling, or weakness in her lower extremities. 

Regarding her hypertension, patient reports good control with home monitoring using a blood pressure cuff as previously recommended. She states she has been watching her diet with support from her boyfriend. She continues to take lisinopril as prescribed and needs a refill. Patient reports mild nasal congestion attributed to seasonal allergies.

## PHYSICAL EXAM
Vital signs: Within normal limits with well-controlled blood pressure.
Cardiovascular: Stable grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, previously documented.
Back: Pain to palpation on the right lateral aspect of the lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension. Negative straight leg raise test.

## RESULTS
Lumbar spine X-ray: Normal bony alignment with no evidence of fracture.
Laboratory studies: No elevated white blood cell count or signs of infection. All labs within normal limits.

## ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
1. Lumbar Strain
   - Prescribe meloxicam 15mg once daily
   - Ice and heat application as needed
   - Referral to physical therapy for back strengthening exercises
   - Continue modified exercise regimen

2. Hypertension, well-controlled
   - Continue lisinopril 10mg daily
   - Prescription refilled
   - Continue home blood pressure monitoring
   - Maintain current dietary modifications

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Ramirez is a 34-year-old female with a past medical history significant for hypertension, who presents today with back pain.

The patient reports she has been walking a lot lately, 30 minutes to an hour or so a day. While walking 6 days ago, she felt her back seize up on her. She is not sure what caused it but thinks she was walking a little faster than usual. She describes the sensation as a spasm. She has been taking ibuprofen and using heat on it but it is still pretty stiff. She denies any known trauma or injury to her back. She notes she has been weightlifting around 3 times a week. She did do deadlifts that day before her walk and thinks she may have been using her back more than her legs to lift. She locates the pain in her mid lower back. She denies any lower extremity numbness, tingling, and weakness.

Regarding her hypertension, she states she has been doing readings at home and that has been looking great. She has been watching her diet which has helped. She is taking lisinopril.

The patient endorses nasal congestion, which she attributes to her seasonal allergies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion from seasonal allergies.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses bilateral low back pain and stiffness.
• Neurological: Denies numbness.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation along the right lateral aspect of her lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension. Negative straight leg raise.

RESULTS

Back x-ray reveals good bony alignment with no obvious fracture.

Labs: All within normal limits.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Ramirez is a 34-year-old female with a past medical history significant for hypertension, who presents today with back pain.

Back pain.
• Medical Reasoning: She experienced a spasm-like pain in her back while walking approximately 6 days ago. She has also been lifting weights recently. Her lumbar spine x-ray was unremarkable and her recent labs were normal. I believe she has a lumbar strain.
• Medical Treatment: We will initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily.
• Specialist Referrals: We will refer her to physical therapy to work on strengthening exercises.
• Patient Education and Counseling: She may apply ice and heat to the area.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: This is well controlled with lisinopril and dietary modifications based on home monitoring.
• Medical Treatment: She will continue lisinopril 10 mg daily. This was refilled today.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged her to continue with home monitoring and report any elevated blood pressures to me.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

</gold_response>

For each of the following criteria, rate the response on a scale of 1 to 5 (1 = very poor, 5 = excellent),
and provide a short justification for your score.

Evaluation Criteria:

}

Ensure the output is valid JSON:

  maintain valid JSON formatting.
- Do not include any additional information in the output.

accuracy.explanation: The note accurately reflects the conversation: onset and mechanism of back pain, lack of neurologic symptoms, home BP control, medication use, and seasonal allergies are correctly documented. Physical exam details (right lateral lumbar tenderness, pain with flexion/extension, negative straight leg raise, stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur) and results (normal lumbar X-ray, labs without leukocytosis) are precise. The plan (meloxicam 15 mg daily, ice/heat, PT referral, continue lisinopril 10 mg with refill) matches the encounter. No contradictory or incorrect statements.

completeness.explanation: All key elements are included: detailed HPI (walking 30–60 minutes, spasm while walking 6 days ago, recent deadlifts, ibuprofen/heat, ongoing stiffness, denies numbness/tingling/weakness), pertinent ROS (nasal congestion from allergies), vitals summary, pertinent exam findings, imaging and labs, and comprehensive A&P for both lumbar strain and hypertension. Minor items like advising to "report elevated BP readings" and broader negative ROS are not explicitly stated but do not materially affect completeness.

clarity.explanation: The note is well organized with standard sections (HPI, Physical Exam, Results, Assessment and Plan), written clearly and succinctly. Findings and plans are easy to follow and clinically usable. Although a separate "Chief Complaint" section is not present, the HPI clearly states the presenting issue.

input.text:
Doctor-patient dialogue:

[doctor] all right . today i am seeing jose james . uh , date of birth 9/29/1957 . mr . james is a new patient who's having pain in his left shoulder and elbow . he fell five months ago going up a stairs , and the pain has been present since .
[doctor] hi mr . james , i'm doctor isabella . how are you doing ?
[patient] i'm okay . thank you .
[doctor] that's good . that's good . tell me what's brings you in today .
[patient] sure . so i've been having constant pain in my left shoulder and left elbow for a while , about five months or so . hurts all the time . pretty bad at times .
[doctor] mm . that does not sound like fun . it sounds like you injured it going up the stairs ?
[patient] yes , that's correct . it was icy , and i have to walk up a flight of stairs to my house . i stepped and my feet just went out . fell on my left side . seems like my shoulder and wrist took the brunt . it's been hurting since .
[doctor] yeah , that does seem like a likely cause of your symptoms . anything seem to make the pain worse ?
[patient] well , i've always hit the gym and lifted weights . i've been trying to keep with my routine of two days a week , but it's been hard . the pain is worse when i lift , and i have n't been able to lift more than 15 or 20 pounds which is very frustrating .
[doctor] mm-hmm . i can imagine it is when you're so accustomed to your routine .
[patient] exactly . i really enjoy my exercise , but over the past one to two weeks , i've stopped hitting the gym because the pain just was n't worth it honestly . i do keep up with my walking , though . my wife and i walk about 30 minutes almost every day . we have done this since i retired from my office job last year .
[doctor] i do not blame you , mr . james . does anything seem to help the pain that you've tried ?
[patient] not too much . i have iced a bit , but i have not taken anything for the pain . stopping exercise and some ice has helped a bit , but it still hurts enough for me to come to see you .
[doctor] yeah , okay . how about any numbness or tingling ? have you felt that at any point ?
[patient] no , doc . just pain . no tingling or numbless , numbness , thankfully .
[doctor] understood . understood . all right . well , let's go ahead and take a look and see what's going on .
[patient] sounds good . thank you .
[doctor] okay . use my general physical exam template . mr . james , i'm going to gently press around your shoulder and elbow here to see where your pain might be stemming from . just let me know when it hurts .
[patient] okay . it hurts when you press there on my elbow and here on my shoulder .
[doctor] okay . left shoulder and elbow , tender sa space , no warmth , erythema or deformity . positive hawkins-kennedy and neer's test . normal proximal and distar , distal upper extremity strength . intact median radial ulnar sensation and abduction to 90 degrees . normal empty tan , can test . okay , mr . james , w-what i think you are dealing with is impingement syndrome of your left shoulder . i do n't think there's an additional injury or issue with your wrist , but because everything is connected , you're experiencing pain in your wrist because of your shoulder . we do see this type of issue when someone has a fall , so it's good you came to see us , you came in to see us so we could help .
[patient] so what are the possible treatments ?
[doctor] well , we have a few options you can try . first option would be to start with physical therapy . i would recommend two sessions per week as well as any other exercises they give you to do at home . we can start there and if that does n't improve your pain , then we could try a cortisone injection .
[patient] i like the idea of starting with the physical therapy and have a next step if it does n't help . i am not opposed to a shot but would like to try the therapy first .
[doctor] all right . great . i'll get a referral order , and they will call you within the next day or two to get you scheduled .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] mm-hmm . also , please continue to ice , especially your shoulder , and rest as much as you can .
[patient] okay . i will .
[doctor] give us a call or email us if you have symptoms worsen , if your symptoms worsen or do not improve with the therapy .
[patient] will do . thank you . i appreciate your help .
[doctor] you're welcome . have a great day .
[patient] you too .
[doctor] all right . assessment is impingement syndrome of left shoulder . plan discussed with patient . referral is requested for dr. martha rivera to be in physical therapy two days per week .

output.text:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder and elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Jose James is a 64-year-old male who presents for left shoulder and elbow pain.

The patient reports falling on his hand while going up stairs 5 months ago and has been experiencing constant pain since. He admits he was continuing to complete strength training exercises at least 2 times per week, however, he was unable to lift more than 15-20 pounds due to the pain.

During the past 1-2 weeks, Mr. James has discontinued strength training activities. Additionally, he has iced the inflicted areas, denies taking any pain medications, and reports his pain has slightly improved but it is still rather constant. He denies tingling and numbness.

The patient walks 30-minutes most days of the week.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Retired last year, was an office worker.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Musculoskeletal
Left shoulder and elbow, tender subacromial space. No warmth, erythema, or deformity. Positive Hawkins-Kennedy and Neer’s test. Normal proximal and distal upper extremity strength. Intact median, radial, ulnar sensation. Abduction to 90 degrees. Normal empty can test.

ASSESSMENT

• Impingement syndrome of left shoulder

Jose is a 64-year-old male who was seen today for impingement syndrome of his left shoulder, likely related to a fall he incurred 5 months ago.

PLAN

Today I discussed conservative options for left shoulder impingement with the patient, who opted to try physical therapy 2 session per week. Cortisone injection was discussed as an option if the physical therapy does not successfully reduce his pain. Additionally, I recommended continued ice and rest.

INSTRUCTIONS

email, or call if symptoms worsen or do not resolve.

completions.text:
# Clinical Note

## HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Jose James, DOB 9/29/1957, is a 66-year-old male presenting as a new patient with complaints of constant left shoulder and elbow pain for approximately 5 months. The pain began after a fall on ice while climbing stairs to his home, where he landed on his left side. The patient reports the pain is worse with weight lifting, which has limited his ability to lift more than 15-20 pounds. Due to pain severity, he has stopped his regular gym routine of twice weekly weight lifting over the past 1-2 weeks, though he continues to walk 30 minutes daily with his wife. He retired from an office job last year. The patient has tried icing with minimal relief and has not taken any pain medications. He denies any numbness or tingling in the affected areas.

## PHYSICAL EXAM
Left shoulder and elbow examination reveals tenderness in the subacromial space. No warmth, erythema, or deformity noted. Positive Hawkins-Kennedy and Neer's tests. Normal proximal and distal upper extremity strength. Intact median, radial, and ulnar sensation. Shoulder abduction limited to 90 degrees. Normal empty can test.

## RESULTS
No diagnostic imaging or laboratory tests were performed during this visit.

## ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
1. Impingement syndrome of left shoulder
2. Plan:
   - Physical therapy referral to Dr. Martha Rivera for twice weekly sessions
   - Home exercise program as prescribed by physical therapist
   - Continue ice therapy, especially to shoulder
   - Rest as tolerated
   - Consider cortisone injection if symptoms do not improve with physical therapy
   - Patient to follow up if symptoms worsen or do not improve with therapy

completeness.explanation: All key elements from the conversation are captured: symptom duration and context, mechanism of injury, aggravating/relieving factors, functional impact on exercise, relevant social context (retired office worker, regular walking), ROS (no numbness/tingling), detailed MSK exam findings, assessment (left shoulder impingement), and a comprehensive plan including PT frequency, provider, conservative measures, escalation (cortisone), and follow-up instructions. No clinically important elements from the encounter are missing.

clarity.explanation: The note is well organized with standard clinical headings (HPI, Physical Exam, Results, Assessment and Plan), uses clear, concise language, and is easy for clinicians to follow. While there is no explicit "Chief Complaint" header, the HPI clearly states the presenting problem, maintaining overall clarity.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Upper respiratory infection.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan Harris is a 57-year-old male with a past medical history significant for coronary artery bypass grafting, hyperlipidemia, and OCD, who presents with an upper respiratory infection.

The patient reports that about a week ago he started to get a cold, which has worsened in the last 2 or 3 days. He endorses some postnasal drip for the beginning of the week, however, it has seemed to move into his chest. He denies chest pain other than his chest congestion. He was able to exercise prior to getting sick. He denies anyone else being sick in his house. He denies fever and shortness of breath.

Regarding his high cholesterol, he states he has been pretty good for the most part. He did a little travel over the last week or so and his diet was not great but for the most part it is pretty good. He is on Crestor 20 mg a day and is tolerating it well. He denies any muscle aches. He had his bypass grafting last year and is doing great.

The patient is fully vaccinated for COVID-19.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fevers.
• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Endorses post nasal drip.
• Cardiovascular: Endorses chest congestion.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Psychiatric: Endorses obsessive compulsive disorder.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neck: Positive cervical lymphadenopathy
• Respiratory: Rhonchi and wheezing bilaterally.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Oxygen Saturation: 96%.

RESULTS

Lipid panel: Within normal limits.

COVID-19 test: Positive

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan Harris is a 57-year-old male with a past medical history significant for coronary artery bypass grafting, hyperlipidemia, and OCD who presents today for upper respiratory symptoms.

COVID-19 Positive.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient presents with upper respiratory symptoms and his COVID-19 test was positive today. He has received both doses of the vaccination. His symptoms seem to be very mild at this time. His oxygenation is good at 96%.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I advised him to quarantine for 10 days and we discussed that he should try to avoid family members. I asked him to call me if his symptoms worsen.

Hypercholesterolemia.
• Medical Reasoning: He is doing well on Crestor 20 mg once a day. His cholesterol looked good on his most recent lipid panel.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged him to continue to watch his diet.
• Additional Testing: We will go ahead and order another lipid panel for 6 months.
• Medical Treatment: He can continue Crestor 20 mg once a day.

History of coronary artery bypass grafting.
• Medical Reasoning: He underwent coronary artery bypass grafting approximately 1 year ago. His coronary artery disease seems to be under control currently. He denies chest pain.
• Additional Testing: We will do a stress test in 6 months.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

completions.text:
# Clinical Note

## HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Logan is a 57-year-old male with a past medical history significant for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), hyperlipidemia, and OCD, who presents with an upper respiratory infection. The patient reports that about a week ago, he started to get a cold, which in the last 2-3 days has moved into his chest. He initially experienced post-nasal drip at the beginning of the week, which then progressed to his upper chest. The patient denies sinus pain, shortness of breath, and significant fever, though he thought he might have had a slight fever. He has received both COVID-19 vaccines. No one else in his household is sick. The patient has been adhering to his cholesterol diet, though he reports some dietary indiscretion during recent travel. He denies muscle aches from his statin medication. The patient reports no chest pain other than congestion and has been able to exercise regularly before becoming ill.

## PHYSICAL EXAM
Vital signs are within normal limits with oxygen saturation at 96%. Physical examination reveals cervical lymphadenopathy. Lung examination shows bilateral ronchi and some wheezing.

## RESULTS
Lipid panel is overall good, requiring no changes to current management. COVID-19 test is positive.

## ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
1. COVID-19 infection: Patient has a mild case, likely due to vaccination status. Plan includes:
   - Quarantine for 10 days
   - Avoid household family members
   - Take time off work
   - Supportive management
   - Call if symptoms worsen

2. Hyperlipidemia: Well-controlled on current therapy. Plan includes:
   - Continue Crestor 20mg daily
   - Continue dietary modifications
   - Repeat lipid panel in 6 months

3. Coronary Artery Disease s/p CABG: Currently stable. Plan includes:
   - Continue current management
   - Schedule stress test in 6 months
   - Patient to continue exercise regimen when recovered from COVID-19

Annual exam.

She states that she has been going to therapy every week, which has helped her manage her symptoms. The patient notes that she is sleeping well at night and has been getting a full 8 hours. She denies any thoughts of self-harm or harming others.

The patient states that she has been checking her blood pressure at home. She notes that her blood pressure has fluctuated lately. She states that she has not had a normal reading in a couple of weeks. The patient has continued utilizing her medications.

She states that her diet has been a little all over the place. The patient notes that she has been working more hours. She reports that she has had some headaches, however, she thought that it was related to her increased screen time.

The patient states that her right carpal tunnel release has been doing well. She denies numbness or tingling in her hands or fingers.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Endorses blood pressure issues.
• Neurological: Endorses headaches.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: Elevated.

RESULTS

Laboratory studies are all within normal limits.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Christine Flores is a 63-year-old female presenting for her yearly exam.

Depression.
• Medical Reasoning: She is doing well and managing this with medication and weekly therapy.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current regimen.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Her blood pressures have been fluctuating lately. She does admit to dietary indiscretion due to her increased workload.

• Patient Education and Counseling: She should continue to monitor this at home and follow up in 1 month.

Carpal tunnel release.
• Medical Reasoning: She is doing well 2 years postoperatively and is asymptomatic at this time.
• Patient Education and Counseling: She will contact us if her symptoms return.

completions.text:
# CLINICAL NOTE

## HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Christine is a 63-year-old female presenting for her routine yearly examination. She has a history of hypertension, depression, and a right carpal tunnel release performed two years ago. She reports her depression is well-managed with medication and weekly therapy sessions. She is sleeping well, getting 8 hours of sleep, and denies any suicidal ideation. Regarding her hypertension, she reports her blood pressure readings have been fluctuating (both high and low) over the past couple of weeks despite medication compliance. She attributes this partly to work stress, increased work hours, and poor dietary habits, including frequent consumption of frozen meals due to lack of time for grocery shopping and meal preparation. She reports occasional headaches, which she attributes to prolonged computer screen use. Her right carpal tunnel release is doing well with no recurrence of symptoms.

## PHYSICAL EXAM
Physical examination reveals clear lungs, no cervical adenopathy, no signs of hyperthyroidism, and regular heart rhythm without murmurs. Neurological examination shows equal grip strength bilaterally, intact sensation, and good muscle strength in the lower extremities. Pulses are good. Overall, the physical examination is normal.

## RESULTS
Blood pressure is elevated in the office today. Laboratory results are essentially normal.

## ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
1. Hypertension: Blood pressure is elevated. Plan to increase lisinopril from current dose to 10 mg daily. Patient to monitor blood pressure at home and return for follow-up in one month.

2. Depression: Currently well-controlled with medication and therapy. No changes to current management plan at this time.

3. Status post right carpal tunnel release: No current symptoms. Patient advised to report any recurrence of numbness, tingling, or other symptoms.

Patient to return to clinic in one month for blood pressure follow-up.
